conclusion: Analyze velocity-time graphs to determine if the displacement difference is continuously increasing.
The image shows two velocity-time graphs, labeled A and B, both are parabolas.
Displacement is calculated by integrating velocity over time.
For object A, the area under its velocity-time graph from 0 to t1 represents its displacement.
For object B, the area under its graph from 0 to t1 represents its displacement.
The difference in displacement is given by the difference in these areas.
If velocity of A is greater than B at all times, the displacement difference will continuously increase.
If there is a time interval where velocity of B is greater than A, the displacement difference might not continuously increase.
The image does not provide explicit velocity values, so we cannot definitively conclude the difference in displacement is continuously increasing.
Final conclusion: No, the difference in displacement is not necessarily continuously increasing.
